Many of the non-alphanumeric characters were positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these were based on mechanical typewriters, not electric typewriters. Mechanical typewriters followed the standard set by the Remington No. 2 (1878), the first typewriter with a shift key, and the shifted values of 23456789- were "#$%_&'() – early typewriters omitted 0 and 1, using O (capital letter o) and l (lowercase letter L) instead, but 1! and 0) pairs became standard once 0 and 1 became common. Thus, in ASCII !"#$% were placed in second column, rows 1–5, corresponding to the digits 1–5 in the adjacent column. Different phases of digestion take place including: the cephalic phase , gastric phase, and intestinal phase. The cephalic phase occurs at the sight, thought and smell of food, which stimulate the cerebral cortex. Taste and smell stimuli are sent to the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata. After this it is routed through the vagus nerve and release of acetylcholine. Gastric secretion at this phase rises to 40% of maximum rate. Acidity in the stomach is not buffered by food at this point and thus acts to inhibit parietal (secretes acid) and G cell (secretes gastrin) activity via D cell secretion of somatostatin. The gastric phase takes 3 to 4 hours. It is stimulated by distension of the stomach, presence of food in stomach and decrease in pH. Distention activates long and myenteric reflexes. The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s. Species are increasingly being moved by humans (on purpose and accidentally). In some cases the invaders are causing drastic changes and damage to their new habitats (e.g.: zebra mussels and the emerald ash borer in the Great Lakes region and the lion fish along the North American Atlantic coast). Some evidence suggests that invasive species are competitive in their new habitats because they are subject to less pathogen disturbance. Others report confounding evidence that occasionally suggest that species-rich communities harbor many native and exotic species simultaneously while some say that diverse ecosystems are more resilient and resist invasive plants and animals. An important question is, "do invasive species cause extinctions?" Many studies cite effects of invasive species on natives, but not extinctions. In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon was still in Egypt.[note 5] After a difficult crossing over the Alps, the French army entered the plains of Northern Italy virtually unopposed. While one French army approached from the north, the Austrians were busy with another stationed in Genoa, which was besieged by a substantial force. The fierce resistance of this French army, under André Masséna, gave the northern striking force precious time to carry out their operations with little interference. After spending several days looking for each other, the two armies finally collided at the Battle of Marengo on June 14. General Melas had a numerical advantage, fielding about 30,000 Austrian soldiers while Napoleon commanded 24,000 French troops. The first significant work that expressed scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, was Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds (1686). The book was produced specifically for women with an interest in scientific writing and inspired a variety of similar works. These popular works were written in a discursive style, which was laid out much more clearly for the reader than the complicated articles, treatises, and books published by the academies and scientists. Charles Leadbetter's Astronomy (1727) was advertised as "a Work entirely New" that would include "short and easie [sic] Rules and Astronomical Tables." The first French introduction to Newtonianism and the Principia was Eléments de la philosophie de Newton, published by Voltaire in 1738. Initially, the group was called "bums" because it referred to a group of fans who were at most games, and since those games were all day games, it was assumed they did not work. Many of those fans were, and are still, students at Chicago area colleges, such as DePaul University, Loyola, Northwestern University, and Illinois-Chicago. Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. The tram picked up the current through a plough (U.S. "plow") accessed through a narrow slot in the road. In the United States, much (though not all) of the former streetcar system in Washington, D.C. (discontinued in 1962) was operated in this manner to avoid the unsightly wires and poles associated with electric traction. The same was true with Manhattan's former streetcar system. In 1877, Thomas Edison invented the phonograph. Unlike the phonautograph, it was capable of both recording and reproducing sound. Despite the similarity of name, there is no documentary evidence that Edison's phonograph was based on Scott's phonautograph. Edison first tried recording sound on a wax-impregnated paper tape, with the idea of creating a "telephone repeater" analogous to the telegraph repeater he had been working on. Although the visible results made him confident that sound could be physically recorded and reproduced, his notes do not indicate that he actually reproduced sound before his first experiment in which he used tinfoil as a recording medium several months later. The tinfoil was wrapped around a grooved metal cylinder and a sound-vibrated stylus indented the tinfoil while the cylinder was rotated. The recording could be played back immediately. Tensions over rising Polish nationalism and the economic effects of the Continental System led to renewed confrontation with Russia. To enforce his blockade, Napoleon launched an invasion of Russia in the summer of 1812. The resulting campaign witnessed the catastrophic collapse of the Grand Army, forcing the French to retreat, as well as leading to the widespread destruction of Russian lands and cities. In 1813, Prussia and Austria joined Russian forces in a Sixth Coalition against France. A chaotic military campaign in Central Europe eventually culminated in a large Allied army defeating Napoleon at the Battle of Leipzig in October. The next year, the Allies invaded France and captured Paris, forcing Napoleon to abdicate in April 1814. He was exiled to the island of Elba. In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia

Reviews of the various editions of Windows 8 have been mixed. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Starting in 1736 under Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest territorial extent since the Sassanid Empire, briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time. During the 19th century, Iran irrevocably lost swaths of its territories in the Caucasus which made part of the concept of Iran for centuries, to neighboring Imperial Russia. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps." Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. Unofficially, Serbs and Croats typically called the language "Serbian" or "Croatian", respectively, without implying a distinction between the two, and again in independent Bosnia and Herzegovina, "Bosnian", "Croatian", and "Serbian" were considered to be three names of a single

By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree species. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. The sides of the field are marked by white sidelines, the goal line is marked in white, and white lines are drawn laterally across the field every 5 yards (4.6 m) from the goal line. These lateral lines are called "yard lines"

In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God who punishes evil, the moral order of society was undermined. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. This has caused minor controversy, but is largely recognized as not lending the school any significant advantage, since players receive no athletic and little physical training during their missions. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. This winter precipitation maximum is quite unusual for humid continental climates, which most commonly have a late spring or early summer

The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. The Klan decided to have a week-long Klavern in South Bend. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. The madrasa of al-Qarawīyīn, one of the two surviving madaris that predate the founding of the earliest medieval universities and are thus claimed to be the "first universities" by some authors, has acquired official university status as late as 1947. In 1954, major Serbian and Croatian writers, linguists and literary critics, backed by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, began to gather from all over Slavic countries to form the League of Writers from Yugoslavia. The project's initiators were Ivan Golac and Vjekoslav Kovačić.

The League began by gathering Serbian and Croatian writers in Belgrade to promote Serbian language and literature. Then the writers gathered in Zagreb in 1960, where the second meeting of the League was held. In August 1961, the third meeting of the Writers' League was held, at which the project of a Serbian journal, "Dalmatinska jezera", was founded. The journal, directed by Milivoje Župančić, is still being published today.

An adolescent's environment plays a huge role in their identity development. While most adolescent studies are conducted on white, middle class children, studies show that the quality of social resources adolescents receive from their families is a stronger and more lasting factor than family income. For example, research by Adeyemo and colleagues has shown that poverty in adolescence is an important factor in adolescent drug use. More recently, Adeyemo (2005) demonstrated that adolescents from lower socioeconomic backgrounds are more likely to become chronic drug users than adolescents from higher socioeconomic backgrounds, while providing other family-based variables such as family composition, stability, and emotional support did not protect from drug use for lower socioeconomic groups of adolescents. These findings are consistent with the Adeyemo study (2005) where the researchers showed that poverty among youth is positively related to the severity of drug problems, as well as other forms of substance use. As a result of these studies, it is clear that poverty is a significant factor in adolescents' substance use.

The interior of the tower has a single nave and two western chapels (1222 and 1235) as well as an arcaded hall with a double arcade, dating to 1282. Early reviews were mixed in their assessment. Ken Tucker of Entertainment Weekly considered that "As TV, American Idol is crazily entertaining; as music, it is nothing less than a disaster." However, Tim Harris of Rolling Stone said that "the show doesn't have quite the same heft or spark as ABC's America's Got Talent," and that, despite the singing talent, "American Idol may soon turn out to be as predictable as NBC's Dance Dance Revolution." Similarly, Marilynn K. Yens of The New York Times felt that "American Idol seems more like the America's Got Talent of the pop world than the reality-show musical competition it's been aiming to be." However, Stephen Holden of The New York Times noted that "It's nice to see the singing competitions in a different, looser, lighter mode, and, given the show's star power and potential, this is the first time we've really had anything like a TV show based on that idea."

The palace measures 108 metres (354 ft) by 120 metres (390 ft), is 24 metres (79 ft) high and contains over 77,000 square metres (5,200,000 sq ft). Many rooms in the palace were built to accommodate its illustrious guests and the royal family and their guests, especially those with large and demanding requests. There is one main corridor with a total of 20 rooms; each one has a different theme: "Dinner", "Swan" (traditional Japanese flower decorations), "Flower", "Flower" and "Sea" decorated with porcelain figures, ornaments, and paintings. Other rooms are decorated with wooden or stone-carved figures, which add to the grandeur of the palace and its guests.

To extend and consolidate the dynasty's control in Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in 1588, and, more significantly, in 1591 against the Kazakhs. He also fought against the Uzbeks, with considerable success but a terrible fate for himself and his family. The first campaigns were, in essence, the same as those of his father and predecessor, but from 1589 onward the Kangxi Emperor embarked on a series of wars against the nomadic tribes of Turkestan, using them as the vanguard of an imperial policy that was to have a profound effect on statecraft and on future Chinese history. His armies made their way by the same old routes south of the Oxus River – in 1581 to the border of what is now Uzbek and Kyrgyzstan, continuing on to Afghanistan. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between individuals results in diverse characteristics relating to hair, both physiological and behavioral. In particular, the color and type of hair is critical to proper identification of individual animals, and it may be used to identify individuals within a species. For example, differences in the lengths of an animal's hair can increase the likelihood of recognition during a species identification session. For example, in some situations, the length of one's hair can be a distinguishing factor for identifying one's species, e.g., the length of one's hair can be a distinguishing factor between the three species of bears in one's yard.

Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism, in particular Kant's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond mere "common sense," or even what counts as reason for the masses in the first place. This is why, at least in _Being and Time_, we encounter an explicitly idealistic element.

While the "spirit of transcendental idealism" in Hegel's writings thus takes the form of taking the very notion of truth for which philosophy is supposed to strive (or at least defend), it appears to take its inspiration from the religious tradition, especially Christianity. Even in the case of the _Phenomenology_, this aspect cannot be ignored, a fact which makes _Phenomenology of Spirit_ even more complicated than its other parts, especially Hegel's other major work in the sequence, _Science of Logic_ (a book which he intended to make the first in the sequence), where the religious dimension is less prominent

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the island of Crete by a German archaeologist, Otto J. Brunsvik (1865–1940). Before agriculture came about, the landscape in this area had a diverse mixture of hunter-gatherer inhabitants and semi-nomadic pastoralists and a few fully domesticate cattle and sheep (see Figure 1). Archaeologists argue that the origin of agrarian peoples in this area was from within the human hunter-gatherer population, perhaps as small as 500 individuals (Grenfell & Jepson, 1998). The earliest farmers came from the Mediterranean region.

Knowledge, for Popper, was objective, both in the sense that it is objectively true (or truthlike), and also in the sense that it was known, i.e. by someone (and not simply by the agent), who could have known it to be false. He also said knowledge that a hypothesis is true is not necessary for the hypothesis to be true; this meant that the subjective concept of truth is not essential for knowledge, i.e. this was the thesis of the subjectivity thesis in Popper's philosophy. In the course of his life philosophy took in other concepts as well as knowledge. The concept of truth was one of these, and was closely related to, although not identical with, knowledge. Knowledge, like knowledge in the sense of a true belief, could be achieved by means of a cognitive operation (in this respect Popper uses the term procedure). The landscapes of Thuringia are quite diverse. The far north is occupied by the Harz mountains, followed by the Goldene Aue, a mountain range with peaks similar to the Alps. The southern part is also characterized by alpine terrain. The most remarkable peaks of the Harz are the Eichhofen, Obersulm, Pörntsch or the Miesbach (all about 3,400 meters high). Other alpine summits with a height from about 2,000 to 3,300 meters can be found in the area.

Thuringia is also characterized by the beautiful rivers of the Elbe and Oder. From the mountains of the Harz it is possible to see the Danube and two canals of the Elbe, but here the majority of water comes from rainfall which, in comparison with the Alps, results in short, often intermittent flooding.

Throughout the 14th century, French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility. They ran into difficulties when attempting to expand overseas and when they came across enemies residing further afield in France itself. The king's advisers were aware of this problem but they were also aware that French interests in the Americas might lead them into direct conflict with the Spanish kingdom of New Spain, which, in turn, occupied a prominent position in all of the world's great empires. France, therefore, decided to move from the north to the south and focus on the Americas.

France's first attempt to develop an outpost in the Americas was the founding in 1268 of St. Thomas in the Caribbean island of Hispaniola and later the foundation and eventual seizure of Dominican Santo Domingo. The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma. During the early Jurassic, the supercontinent Pangaea was divided into North and South America, Africa, and Europe ([Fig. 1](#F1){ref-type="fig"}) and the South American supercontinent was divided into Ictinia, Baltica, and Laurasia ([@R11]). In the later Jurassic, Ictinia and Baltica collided to form Laurasia and in the Cretaceous, Laurasia collided with Africa to form Pangaea ([@R13],[@R14]).

Many ground crew at the airport work at the aircraft. A tow tractor pulls the aircraft to one of the airbridges, The ground power unit is used to lift the aircraft from the tow tractor, up the airbridge, and then down to the taxiway.

Ground power is provided by engines to power the airbridges. Engines may be of piston, reciprocating, or turbofan types. The engines are typically connected to the aircraft by means of driveshafts.

Engines are powered by hydraulic jacks, which are hydraulic power sources that use pneumatic pressure to feed hydraulic fluid to different cylinders. This feeds hydraulic fluid to and from the individual cylinder of each engine cylinder bank. The fluid is then used to drive a hydraulic hydraulic pump, which, for example, raises the engine (and attached fuel system) above the ground, where it may be connected to a groundpower system.

The highest position in Islam, caliphate, was claimed by the sultans starting since Murad I, which was established as Ottoman Caliphate. The sultans were the successors of Muhammad; the word ‘caliphate’ is very commonly believed to have a meaning of caliphate of the Muslims.

The caliphate was held for more than a century, but the Ottomans eventually lost it to the Moughnoup movement in the early 1800s. The reason was that the Moughnoup leaders, who followed Sufi tradition, refused to grant it to the Ottomans as a condition for peace. So the caliphship gradually fell into disuse. But in recent decades, the caliphate has once again been revived. In 2015, the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, declared itself as the caliphate of the Islamic Caliphate in Syria and Iraq.

After gaining the Master Sword, Link is cleansed of the magic that kept him in wolf form, obtaining the Shadow Crystal. Now able to use it, Link can change into any of six kinds of creatures: a spider, a fish, a bird, a flying lizard, a dragon and a serpentine beast.

Gameplay
The game is played entirely in the touchscreen display and is made up mainly of combat. Each character has a different combat engine. Link fights by moving his sword, throwing arrows, using his bow, or throwing bombs or stones and by moving his mouse to attack opponents with the sword. While in-game movement involves running and jumping, the movement of the screen can be controlled by pressing both the right and left buttons at the same time. When Link is holding the sword, there is also the option for pressing the circle button (or double-tap if holding the sword as well) to make Link swing the sword.

Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals. Birds also have an efficient breathing system: they breathe more air into their lungs than their heart can use, thus enabling them to get more oxygen into their bodies to meet their needs. They breathe through the trachea or windpipe, which also acts like a fan. They also have a large blood volume and can extract large amounts of oxygen and carbon monoxide.

**Oxygen** is important to virtually all living things, but the main use of oxygen is as a constituent in small organic molecules known as _h2o,_ and the water is important for almost every process, from photosynthesis to the creation of sugars. Oxygen also forms a vital component of the cell membrane for aerobic respiration.

Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents begin to explore the world and attempt to find themselves (Frye et al. [@CIT0023]). In many of these explorations adolescents explore their beliefs, values and interests (Ekkes, Haggard, and van den Berg [@CIT0009]; Frye et al. [@CIT0023]). Identity development therefore, is seen a critical and necessary stage for young people. During this process, adolescents are developing and exploring their ideas of who they are and to some degree their views of the world around them (Byrnes and Thomas [@CIT0007]). Y DNA studies tend to imply a small number of founders in an old population whose members parted and followed different migration paths. A study by Dr Peter Gasser and researchers at The University of Sydney has found that a young healthy person can learn if they are immunised with a common childhood disease such as measles. It is the first time that someone has been shown to exhibit both short term and lasting protection against common childhood diseases in response to immunisation.

"We were really surprised to find that a young, healthy human could learn to recognise which disease they were immunised against. This is an important finding. The implication is that a person's immune system is ready to learn or memorise the type of disease they have been immunised against," said Dr Gasser, a world expert on memory and immunology.

Dr Peter Gasser's paper can be found in the latest edition of the journal Immunity.

Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid in urate crystals. However, unlike reptiles, birds also get rid of the uric acid in a separate excretory system: in the feces. The birds then use uric acid in the blood and in their bones as a crystal form, and the bacteria that inhabit the guts of birds use the uric acid as the nutrient they need in the blood. Uric acid in birds is found at only 0.02 to 0.15 mg/g, compared to 0.8 mg/g in mammals.

Uric acid is a normal waste product for mammals, whose kidneys excrete it in the urine and excrete it in its mineralized form in bones and teeth. Uric acid is also produced in plants by a process called urea excretion. Plant ureases break down urea into carbamic

In Homer's Iliad, the names Danaans (or Danaoi: Δαναοί) and Argives (Argives in Greek) are both mentioned in connection with the battle at Thermopylae, where Xerxes' massive army was defeated. Both Danaans and Argives were associated with the Ionian Greeks and have strong connections with them in myth. Argives were originally settled on Greek islands, from the first century BCE onwards, to provide laborers for construction on them. Around the time of the foundation of Corinth around 250 BCE, Argive residents were encouraged to build their own settlement by their king Iaros, while Danaans were settled in cities such as Miletos and Aegina. The first two names could also refer to the Ionian Greeks and their ancient homeland, from which they had been displaced.

Many modern specialty matches have been devised, with unique winning conditions. The most common of these is the ladder match. In the basic ladder match, the participant who makes it to the top of the ladder in any period wins this period. Any period in which the participant loses more than a point to the participant above him is counted as a loss. Thus, in the final two periods of a four period match, the participant who placed at the start of the final two periods wins the match. A modified ladder match is sometimes used in which the participant in control of the two points above the one that places one point on the ladder wins.
For games such as squash and table tennis, the ladder match is not the best choice. In squash, for example, one player is given a few balls to make the initial play, but he is then removed from the match. A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. As a true predator, it is essential to keep perspective of things. For example, we don’t view a cat roaming around the neighborhood as a true predator. From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and their interactions. Those interactions could range from the electromagnetism of the electron to the strong force, and then on down the ladder, to spin-orbit, weak nuclear, and gravity interactions. As Feynman’s formalism was formalized by groups like the American Institute of Physics, it moved from the realm of simple and pure matrices representing spins and interactions in the electron and hadrons to the more realistic world the computer was to play in.

The study is a departure from previous assertions of a genetic separation between Jewish and non-Jewish populations.

“This discovery suggests that the origins of the Ashkenazi people extend back to the very beginnings of the human community on this planet, more than 100 generations ago,” said Richards, who first suggested the study and is the author of the “European Origin of the Jews” paper on the subject.

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before 1870. In that year, the Montana legislature created the University of Montana at Bozeman to educate Native Americans. In 1887, Bozeman became the state capital. Later, Helena was chosen as the state capital, then Billings. In 1913, The University graduated its first male student. A year later, the first women graduated from the University. In 1975, Montana became the 29th state to abolish slavery in the state. In 1996, Montana became the 29th state to issue driver licenses to non-lawfully present aliens.

On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by Sir George Loring, who became lord chancellor. Loring succeeded to the office of attorney-general on 1 December 1794 when Burke left politics, and was re-elected in succeeding elections. In February 1796, Burke resigned from the House of Commons, but was re-appointed on 7 March. He was appointed Privy Counsellor on 9 November 1796. On 18 April 1797, Burke again stood down from parliament, and on 25 April 1797 he wrote a pamphlet entitled 'The Journal of a Revolutionary Agent'.

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints, nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church. Instead, one will find a table of various materials that are used to make statues — wood, metal, and clay. This makes this church a good place to find out how the statues were made. The sculpting process was once so meticulous and detailed that artists would mold one of the statues into a particular form just before hanging it on the wall. The result was an amazingly lifelike statue.

In this church, however, you will see a typical set of statues. Here is a good place to find statues that have worn in appearance due to use or neglect. As you move through the church, you will see that the statue next to the altar is an older version of the figures in the pews. You’ll find many that have deteriorated as so many other items of the pews have.

The polyphony of Christian a cappella music began to develop in Europe around the late 15th century, with compositions by Josquin des Prez and the Baroque period composer William Byrd. These composers in concert with other European composers such as Beethoven (1770, the "Beethoven Circle") and Brahms (whose father, W. S. P. Barham was a church organist) and American composers, such as Franz Schubert (1837, "The Five" a cappella quintet) and Ralph Vaughan Williams (1894, "The Wreck of the Hesperus"), were instrumental in bringing about its rise. The a cappella, particularly in a vocal group setting, began to gain widespread popular acceptance through publications of a cappella music such as The Cambridge Companion to World-Class a Cappella Music. The a cappella genre peaked in popularity in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

On 13 March, the upper Clyde port of Clydebank near Glasgow was bombed. All but seven of its 12,000 houses were damaged. Many men at the port were away from their posts, but when it was bombed a few other men were at the dock, in the office of the ship's company's paymaster. He was a former policeman and had served with the Royal Yacht _Marlborough_ in the Mediterranean. When the raid was announced in the office and in various other places throughout Clyde, he was away from his workplace. When he returned, his pay was reduced by ten shillings. Despite the threat that it might otherwise have been cancelled, the order was kept and the paymaster went on to make ten shillings out of his pay in the months that followed. With Britain locked in a major war with the United States, President James Madison and the Congress, on May 14, 1812, initiated a naval and land attack on the British in the Battle of Lake Erie just as the war had started. The war began when President James Madison issued an ultimatum to Britain demanding a cessation of hostilities by July 4. Madison wanted Britain out of the war before he could get a new treaty with Britain for their assistance at the war's start. British ships had captured American ships and forced them to run the blockade and the Americans, however, were not about to give up on their independence. The battle was largely fought in and around the British coastal town of Oswego, New York and also in nearby Detroit. Madison wanted to force Britain to give up the naval base, so the British and the American forces attacked each other.

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment, it is not the case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and complicated. They are not limited to the hippocampus and cerebral cortex of humans. In fact, the brain is capable of changing the characteristics of memory according to the situation and moment as the memory itself is shaped by a variety of different factors. The human brain even shows different characteristics from species to species. Because of the dynamic nature of memory and the complexity of brain physiology, it will be extremely challenging for people to accurately and efficiently diagnose and treat memory diseases. Thus, what we cannot ignore is the dynamic mechanism of induction and maintenance of memory.

The United States has become essentially a two-party system. Since a conservative (such as the Republican Party) and liberal (such as the Democratic Party) each have approximately two-thirds of voters, the result is that the two parties are generally regarded as reflecting distinct segments of the public. The parties are also, by custom, defined on ideological grounds—that is, voters may be inclined to favor one party and be more likely to identify with it in a given locality than with the other. At the same time, the two parties tend to define themselves in contradistinction. A presidential candidate from the right-leaning Republican Party is said to be a “ conservative ” and a presidential candidate from the more left-leaning Democratic Party a “ liberal ”. This is a useful distinction, but one that is largely imprecise, since both parties are more or less “ conservative ” or “ liberal ” according to the positions they take on a host of issues,

Darwin was hard at work on his "big book" on Natural Selection, when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace, who was then in Paris for a short visit. It was marked "Wallace, Henry", with a postmark dated 18 June, 1858. Darwin quickly saw that he had been hoaxed. It was in fact a book by Mary Somerville, "Contributions to the Geology of the Antarctic Region, as reported in the year 1858".

As Darwin continued to read "the hoax", and came to appreciate the depth of Wallace's knowledge, he grew to value his friendship with Wallace, and on 29 August 1859 he wrote to the Australian government, expressing gratitude for the introduction he had received from the naturalist who had given him a "good education" in botany. Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages: natural philosophy, logic, medicine, theology, mathematics, astronomy (and astrology) and ethics. The faculty of arts and letters remained separate, as in Western Europe at the time.

The study of the humanities was gradually taken over by the natural sciences, especially medicine. Most people at this time, including the church, believed that the soul or spirits were not material, or that material reality existed only as a spiritual reality.

The study of medicine was carried on in many branches of science, and students of medicine studied the natural sciences, or even the sciences themselves. Some physicians even claimed to restore lost arts; one of them, Johannes Scotus Erigena, a professor of medicine, was a great genius, for he restored logic and rhetoric.

The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only. A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws—the rules governing its activities. On the other hand, a board-only organization is a special-purpose nonprofit entity composed of a board of directors of which the general membership of the organization is not necessarily represented on the board.

These distinctions can have a profound impact on how members are treated. For instance, non-profit organizations are typically members-only organizations governed by bylaws that are subject to the same requirements as those governing membership organizations.

For this same reason, even though a nonprofit is governed by a bylaw, it can still be members-only, and its board or officers can be elected only by members. This can create a conflict when the officers elected by members have access to members' funds or a different, personal interpretation of the bylaws than the board adopted without their input.

Fearing the worst, the Romans began a major mobilization, all but pulling out of recently pacified Spain and Gaul. They even established a major garrison town on the coast so as to be on the safe line from Spain. When, in the spring of 402 AD, they learned the Vandals' offensive had failed, the Romans decided to retreat across the Pyrenees and down the valleys of northern Spain. They marched along the coast, but they were intercepted and turned back by the army of the Vandals. The troops were captured and killed. The Vandals were not going to take the Roman provinces.

The Romans then set up a new garrison in the northern Italian city of Fidena, only a few miles south of what is now Rome but which is today a small coastal town. Roman soldiers established a base there under the command of an Italian general, Geminus. With the army of the Vandals occupied, Geminus then marched toward Rome to demand an unconditional surrender

Formal discipline is administered by congregation elders. When a baptized member is accused of committing a serious sin—usually cases of sexual misconduct or charges of apostasy—he is required to bring evidence of his innocence before the local congregational elders. When this has not been done, and the case was referred to a higher ecclesiastical officer—the bishop, pastor, or archbishop—it is usually referred back to the congregation elders and the case is then referred to the district court system for the elders to determine. 

A court case does not need to be a formal lawsuit to be considered valid. In fact, a formal lawsuit is never necessary in order for a court case to be held. Since re-establishing independence, Estonia has styled itself as the gateway between East and West and aggressively pursued economic reform and integration with the West. Estonia is no longer an outpost of Soviet Russia, though the fact that Estonia has long served as a buffer of pro-Russian separatist movements in neighbouring Estonia and the Baltics has made it a point of pride. In 2013, Estonia decided to join NATO but has yet to take part in air strikes against Islamic State (ISIS). In 2016, it passed laws that give legal standing and the right to representation for LGBT citizens in legal proceedings. It is currently facing anti-missile defences designed to protect Estonia against Russian aggression. The Estonian government has also pursued active diplomacy with Germany, the main political and economic patron of Estonia, and the UK. The result is that the West continues to recognise Estonia as a legitimate independent state. Its long-term relationship with the West has largely been based on trade and the promotion of EU integration, with few other considerations.

The increasing dissemination of books in Europe from the 15th to the 17th centuries naturally led to the development of printing presses in most of the Western world. The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", the fact that the invaders stayed in the territory they took is usually overlooked. The Romans, in fact, were forced to abandon a third of what they had conquered. This included the territories of the old Celtic communities, who had had to accept that, after the Roman withdrawal, they now had to contend with populations not belonging to the same group and whose customs and beliefs would have to be different.

This is where the Celtic identity that had emerged during the years immediately after the Roman withdrawal begins to take on more and more importance. Indeed, the Celtic identity will become the starting point for a much wider range of questions about identity and self-representation, and it will also become the point of departure for new movements of nationalism. The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south, although the northern (primarily Germany, France and Great Britain) and southern (primarily Italy and Spain) cultures share much. In northern Europe, higher education is often a state monopoly in Germany and France, a national university in Great Britain, and a national university in other countries where institutions of higher education are state operated but are still run by the states in their own unique ways (see Universities). These institutions have very different educational requirements from those of the south—in north Europe, for example, students are required to pay to attend institutions of higher education, to study in private rather than public institutions, and to be awarded only academic degrees (see Further education).

In the United States and Canada, higher education is provided by mostly private corporations. These universities are often associated with various religious or secular charities. The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages, mathematics, and Greek. It was the most important and influential school report in the history of American higher education. Its author, the Yale president Thomas C. Cooper, insisted that the institution should offer the Latin and Greek languages. This was an unprecedented challenge for a colonial university. And in America, it was a foregone conclusion that any new course in an English language would be considered a threat to national identity—a foreign language curriculum. The Latin and Greek departments at Yale had to defend themselves for over twelve years before this particular report, the last written by the president, appeared in print.

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. A single type of organism is added to the growth medium and is allowed to grow, whereby microorganism growth is determined by observable properties of the microorganism. Traditionally, biological culturing of a single microorganism such as bacteria has been the only method of identifying microbial growth. Microorganism cultivation requires specialized laboratory space with incubators, air locks, and the collection and analysis of samples.
In modern biological culturing techniques, more complex microbial growth is measured in microliter volumes of growth media or in low volumes of bacterial suspensions. Because of the limited available volume of liquid in a typical biological culture, most microbiological cultures are performed in closed-system culture vessels or in low volume liquid handling techniques. Adolescence marks a rapid change in one's role within a family. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence in the family without parents' permission by mid-childhood. By the end of the third decade, children's emerging independence is in full swing. Despite increasing autonomy, children, like adolescents, still have some degree of family contact. In addition, youth still spend more time with their caregivers than with their parents. Parents still play a significant role in the lives of their children, even during the adolescent years. A variety of factors contributes to the high incidence of psychopathology during adolescence, including: increased life stresses such as academic pressures, interpersonal relationships, and violence; emotional dysregulation resulting from the developmental shift to autonomy; and an increased risk of mental disorders such as depression, suicidal ideation, anxiety, and low self-esteem (Herman & Rosen, 2017). The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues. In May 1987, Gaddafi announced the creation of the Libyan Investment Authority. This investment vehicle would be set up as a sovereign wealth fund that would attract private cash investment from around the world in the form of export licences for the development of Libyan assets. The investment project has so far attracted US$2 billion, although most of this money comes from the Middle East.

With the creation of the sovereign wealth fund, the idea of Libya as an investment option grew wider. More recently, in the late 1990s Gaddafi decided to make Libya a financial centre with the establishment of the Libyan Stock Exchange, a currency market. Both these steps demonstrate that Gaddafi was beginning to understand the importance of investments in Libya. The term "subject" here means "in a state of war"—a "state of war," in Locke's terms, is "a _contrariety,"_ where the antagonists are "neighbors" of a kind, who do not "consider" or "admonish" each other. Under the Capetian dynasty France slowly began to expand its authority over the nobility, growing out of the Île-de-France to exert far-reaching influence in what is now called the 'French League'.

From 877 the dukes of the French _apartements_, or _locaes_, became more firmly controlled by their overlords. The local lordship was now known simply as a _région_ and the duke who controlled it could enforce any of a range of decrees binding _on châme_, 'on the lord', but also 'on the peasant'. The system was formalised in 883 by an edict issued by Louis the Pious, who had succeeded his mother as Emperor Charles the Bald. The concept of racial differences became an important topic of social and scientific debate. The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals, the Soviet Union (USSR) and the United States (US), to see who would reach the Moon first. At one point the two countries were tied at the height of their Cold War, with the world’s two superpowers vying for the most powerful rocket and then space exploration. Despite being a world war that caused the death of nearly 20,000 crewmen, the rivalry never waned, so much that it was nicknamed the Space Race, the word being chosen to signify that Russia and the US, by virtue of their position in space, were the best at space exploration. The rivalry lasted almost 15 years, until the Soviet Union finally landed an American man on the Moon. The US and Soviet flags were erected to mark the occasion. It was the greatest triumph of human civilization so far, and at the same time the death throes of a great rivalry.

After Cassander's death in 298 BCE, however, Demetrius, who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet, invaded Macedon, seized its territory, and expelled Philip into exile in the Aegean island of Rhodes. Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period, plenty of sunshine, and a moderate rainfall, usually from 600 to 1,200 mm (about 24 to 60 inches).

**Stocking Rate** The ratio between the number of plants that would be raised, if a crop were grown in the field for one year, and the total number of plants planted.

**Surface area** A measure of the amount of usable surface area. It is usually expressed in square meter(s) or square (feet).

**Tax payment** A payment the farmer receives for taxes collected for government, usually over a limited time. This payment covers a percentage of the total tax amount and provides a benefit to the farmer in many cases.

**Technical field** Fields of the best land in the field, which are usually the only good ones left. They are usually considered a type of lowland cultivable land. _See also under soil._

In the spring of 1834, Chopin attended the Lower Rhenish Music Festival in Aix-la-Chapelle with Hiller, his violinist, at the invitation of Hiller's mentor, Jean-Jacques Daviaud. Daviaud, a leading figure in the generation of French Romantic composers, had written a number of works for Hiller who used the pianist Anton Rubinstein and violinist Camille Saint-Saéz as his accompanists. When Chopin was shown round the performance hall, he fell under the spell of the music and became one of its most enthusiastic patrons. One of the composers he most admired was Joseph-Edmond Béra, an Italian violin maker with whom he had already exchanged a friendly visit years before.

Intel had tried unsuccessfully to push Apple to migrate the Macintosh platform to Intel chips. Apple concluded that Intel's CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) instruction set was just not up to the task.

The two companies settled early in 1997, with an agreement to license the software and hardware of the Apple II operating system in exchange for some rights in the Apple II OS. Under the agreement, Intel purchased ownership of the Apple II hardware and transferred to the company that Apple wanted as its licensee. As part of the deal, Apple retained its exclusive rights to all of the Apple II's hard-wired hardware, software and documentation.

The agreement also gave Intel rights to develop other new products in return for royalties from the IBM PC (as well as support for the IBM PC hardware), the Apple III, the Apple Macintosh, and the Apple II Plus (the IBM PC/XT and its sister products were not re-branded).

With respect to these outer regions, the Qing maintained imperial control, with the emperor acting as Mongol khan, patron of Tibetan Buddhism and protector of Muslims and other ethnic minorities. He resided at Yumungong, near Beijing. The Yumungong palace had a garden surrounded by a high wall. The emperor resided in the garden and was often accompanied by Mongol chiefs and their ladies.

The Qing also permitted missionaries to proselytize, including the Protestant clergy of the time (the Nestorian Protestant Church, which split from the Chaldean Church in the 1830s). Qing missions were funded by means of taxes upon Chinese merchants. Some missionaries worked with indigenous peoples to advance their interests and some did little more than collect taxes.

Jefferson and James Madison's conceptions of separation have long been debated. Jefferson refused to issue Proclamations of Thanksgiving sent to him by Congress during both his first and second terms. In his Farewell Address, Madison proposed the idea of Thanksgiving as a national holiday; however he also proposed establishing an annual Thanksgiving Day celebration that would be marked with Thanksgiving services and displays. On June 9, 1817, the Second Congress passed the Twining Resolution calling for an annual celebration of Thanksgiving. The Twining Resolution passed the U.S. Senate by a vote of 17–0 and the U.S. House of Representatives by a vote of 205–1. The Twining Resolution was the first legislative proposal that offered a formal expression of Christian values and was followed by resolutions honoring Thanksgiving Day each year.[8] The Twining Resolution went into effect by proclamation on June 23, 1817.[9]

Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a particular sexual orientation, while an inclusive boundary arises when a person adopts many different types of sexual orientations simultaneously. And, both boundaries are likely to influence how the other person feels about both the type of sexual orientation, as well as the person's sexual orientation.

And, what type sexual orientation a person has plays an important role in whether they feel accepted or not. If a person feels like they are being accepted even if they don't fully fit in, their boundary may be inclusive. And, if they feel like they are not accepted even when they fully fit in, their boundary may be strictly exclusive, which might reflect how much they value their personal freedom.

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is particularly true for heavy cranes. Accordingly, each section of line that feeds the hopper car receiving one or more of the hoppers on the respective crane must therefore be positioned such that the hopper car is located in a separate isolation line section. Due to crane size and weight the isolation of the separate hopper car lines is time consuming, labour-intensive and potentially hazardous for the crane operator.
The risk of line out-of-phase supply mixing of the separate hopper car lines is increased when a hopper car line is fed with a hopper from the front using a hopper feeder station and then the line must be diverted to the backside of the crane. In addition to the classical restaurants, Paris has several other kinds of traditional eating places. The café arrived in Paris in the 17th century, when the French royal chefs met in cafés to plan menus for the upcoming year. In the 18th century, Napoleon decreed the creation of French ci-devant cuisine, in which the French chefs invented new dishes in which they themselves were deeply involved. From the 1820s to the middle of the 19th century, food in Paris was eaten during the day, with menus often containing dishes intended for the evening or for special occasions. The great dining halls of Paris served as social centers where people could meet and socialize and meet the French elite.

One reason why some consider them college music is that there is a school of study dedicated exclusively to the study of a cappella. Dorgon's controversial July 1645 edict (the "haircutting order") forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and cut their beards for the first time. The order was to remain in effect until the end of the eighteenth century, when male heads of the gentry were to be again cut, albeit less dramatically. It remains a matter of dispute whether this edict was to be put into practice (at least temporarily) in the spring of 1868; some argue that the policy was never put into effect.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers, family, and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent. As an example, a study has shown that adolescents who spend more time playing with their peer, have better academic success later on in life.[@bib1] However, one of the most prevalent and debilitating psychosocial outcomes in adolescence is bullying, as it occurs in both verbal and physical forms. In addition, bullying has been linked to higher rates of depression, antisocial behavior, and suicide.[@bib2], [@bib3] In a large Swedish study examining bullying, physical bullying was the fourth most occurring type of bullying, behind verbal bullying, emotional bullying, and cyberbullying.[@bib4] However, despite the severity of symptoms of emotional, verbal, and cyberbullying experienced by many young individuals, there are no comprehensive bullying prevention programs available to curb all forms of bullying.

Most fatty acids are non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. Therefore, the human body has to store these fatty acids as fat, as opposed to using them directly in metabolism as energy or making energy from them to produce other compounds.[7] The production of fatty acids by the body is a matter of self-limiting competition among the various organs and tissues of the body for available nutrients, such as essential fatty acid precursors.[7] Therefore, there is no single human tissue that is able to produce fatty acids.[7] Instead, there are a number of different cell types including adipocytes (fat cells), hepatocytes (liver cells), myocytes (heart cells), and capillaries, bone cells and cartilage cells that contribute to the storage and release of fatty acids from the body.[7] In the fatty acid synthetic pathways, long-chain fatty acyl-CoA

Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident, President Harry S. In mainland China, the Japanese 3rd, 6th, and 40th Divisions massed at Yueyang and advanced southward in three columns and struck at Hai–an–ke–nam, the capital of north China (Nanjing prefecture). The 2nd Chinese Brigade reached a swamp on the Nanjing Railway north of Hai–an–ke–nam (Shui Ping Creek), and the Japanese 5th Division advanced through the marshy area and destroyed railroad and bridge obstructions. The Japanese then began to attack the 6th Chinese Brigade. Despite the Chinese fighting to delay the 3rd Division, they were overwhelmed; the Japanese captured 20,000 prisoners and the 6th Chinese Brigade captured more than 20,000 more.

Aftermath
The Japanese continued to advance but encountered a series of fierce resistance from the Chinese troops. After the 4th Division engaged the Japanese and lost, a Chinese counterattack captured their forward positions on the day of the battle.

Nanjing, one of the nation's most important cities for over a thousand years, is recognized as one of the Four Great Ancient Capitals of China, along with Hangzhou, Xi'an and Beijing.

Nanjing is a complex crossroads where East and West meet. It is the most populous and technologically advanced city in China. It is also a political site that continues to exercise historical meaning.

From a cultural point of view, Nanjing offers a variety of architectural, religious and scientific treasures, including the Temple of Heaven in Nanking, the Temple of the Eight Immortals on Huaihai Hill, Tiananmen Square as well as the Forbidden City in Beijing.

The Silk Road has brought together Westerners and local ethnic Chinese who have taken up many of the city's many tourist attractions.

A popular attraction of Nanjing is the Nanjing Massacre Monument, dedicated to the victims of the massacre of thousands during the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests

Before the early 20th century, treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore. Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections started to be developed relatively early, especially by French physician Joseph Lortz (1831--1898).[@bib1], [@bib2], [@bib3] Many different substances have been used to fight infections; however, few are truly "antibiotics" that are capable of completely eradicating even the most resistant pathogens from the infected site. Therefore, it is of prime importance to search for new antimicrobial agents with improved pharmacokinetic, and particularly pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) profiles relative to existing drugs.[@bib4]

A standard adult football match consists of two periods of 45 minutes each, known as halves. Each half runs continuously, meaning that the clock is not stopped or wound and so no time expires during a half. A total of five minutes are taken during a football match for the referee to read out the score of the game. The goal is then awarded to whichever side has received the fewest scored goals and no "penalty" or "handball" decisions are taken.

When a player leaves the pitch between the two halves of a match to have treatment (such as getting a shot of adrenaline or blood pressure medication) or has a drink that has the same effect, he is called off until all the players on the pitch return. During this enforced break, neither the referee nor his assistant is permitted to re-scan the players and restart the game. At the end of play, the referee hands out a whistle to be used in every subsequent game to signal the end of the match.

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills. Peer groups offer members the opportunity to identify with others and develop an identity. The study of developmental and social cognition and how they are affected by communication in peer groups is an emerging area of research and has important real-world consequences for the health and well-being of adolescents. Adolescent social competence is negatively correlated with many physical, mental and behavioral problems among children and adolescents. These include mental health problems including depression, suicide risk, anxiety, substance use, obesity, and poor self-esteem. Among them, poor social competence seems to be the most prevalent, as well as the strongest predictor of all health consequences. Peer communication may be especially important to develop the social competence skills needed to protect adolescents against negative health outcomes as well as foster positive growth. However, despite high interest in the topic, we do not yet understand the influence peer communication has on development, or how it effects physical

In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. He was unable to find a colony for himself, and he died in Philadelphia in 1683.

Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake. Therefore, sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation. During sleep, the neural connections in the hippocampus re-associate to form new memory circuits, and the long-term potentiation and depression of synapses and neuroplasticity at the synapse are both enhanced. Memory consolidation has also been shown to occur on an individual basis. Because sleep deprivation degrades memory, we can infer that sleep has a key role in the consolidation of new information and a key role in the forgetting of old information.

What’s new

This issue of Alzheimer’s Disease & Dementia opens with a discussion of sleep and memory consolidation. In this issue we also show how sleep disturbances and memory impairments can be exacerbated by aging. “The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature.” Literature in all its forms can be seen as a central organizing principle of academia and therefore of society. The academic disciplines are made up of multiple layers of literature, from philosophy to science and even to political ideologies. This study argues that the roots of academia go back to the formation of literature as a discipline. Literature itself was the foundation upon which these disciplines developed. Because of the close relationship between literature and academia, it has been argued that all of the modern sciences may be traced back to the writings of philosophers and poets. Indeed, one of the most influential fields of inquiry of the early modern period has been human and/or literary scholarship. These fields expanded because human inquiry was at that point considered only a secondary aspect of literary inquiry. Van Praag states that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these were not in fact embassies, but rather a way for Europeans to visit this remote and remote region, and to keep their influence alive through the use of diplomatic cover. The first railways in Thuringia had been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines were already in service and, at the start of the 20th century, there were already more than 15,000 km of railways. The major system was expanded in the early 1920s, and in 1934 the Thuringian Railway, which was one of the two important lines in the area, was bought by the state and integrated into the Deutsche Reichsbahn  on a permanent basis. Before 1945, the Thuringian Railway operated a fleet of four narrow-gauge railways.

In 1945, the line was returned to private enterprise. In 1950, three railway subsidiaries were sold to the state: the Thuringian Railway, the Dessau–Hof railway, and the Nuremberg–Döbeln railway. The other part of the network, the Hof Railway, was sold to the state.

Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding plumage".

The winter plumage of the bird, the time of year when the bird is sexually active, is known as the "breeding plumage". This has nothing to do with mating. The winter plumage changes as a bird’s reproductive state changes from breeding to non-breeding, from non-breeding to breeding.
