Viking invasions began in the 9th century, followed by more permanent settlements, particularly along the east coast of Ireland, the west coast of modern Britain, and the Scottish Highlands. Norse Vikings settled coastal settlements (Hiaeste in Norway and Hibernia in the British Isles) along continental Europe (Scandinavia), Greenland and the Faroe Islands. Vikings raided Ireland, Scotland, England, and other areas at will after taking control of them, which, coupled with their raiding had caused such a severe backlash against their actions in Scandinavia, that they were effectively restricted to raiding in Northern Europe; they had no permanent settlements there to maintain. Many of their settlements were constructed in the name of Thor or other gods.

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these are unstable and rapidly react with cellular components like proteins and lipids, leading to DNA damage. They are generally considered to be non-harmful, even though an accumulation in cell and tissue macromolecules will lead to cell death ([@CIT0001]). Nevertheless, a more complex picture is described when considering the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis where free radicals or reactive oxygen species (ROS) contribute to lipid oxidation and cellular dysfunctions as a means to prevent them from reaching toxic levels ([@CIT0001]--[@CIT0003]).

Despite Martin Luther's harsh polemics against his Roman Catholic opponents over issues concerning Mary and the saints, theologians appear to agree that Luther adhered to a similar perspective in his thoughts on sexuality and sin. In 1905, Lord Curzon split the large province of Bengal into a largely Hindu western half and "Eastern Bengal and Assam", a largely Muslim eastern half. Curzon had an ideological hostility to the Muslim East Indian Muslims and sought to achieve "a unitary British India" where there was "no place for Hind-Hussas, or Mohammedan Bhais" and where these communities would no longer be granted their own state. Curzon was also the first Governor General to introduce a compulsory education system for women.

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications than statements about mental phenomena. Physicalism became the default position, although what was to become known as reductionism (taking physicalism as a default position and rejecting anything but it) had been under discussion for some 70 years earlier, in the work of John Stuart Mill, who published his own ‘new’ philosophy in 1864 and by 1866 laid out his case fully for it. The other two options for the default position had been idealism and nominalism, and their rivals in the form and substance of realism, materialism and idealism had been worked out well in the 19th century. It was a matter of which default position could be chosen to take most seriously—and many people had very different ideas. (For a full treatment of this problem see my own book, Realism (2011) and

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by an early non-Sasanian proto-ethnic culture of nomadic nomadic people, who spoke a variety of non-Sasanian languages. They were originally nomadic Bactrian nomads. Following the rise of the Western Han dynasty (202 BC–AD 220), the Zhejiang people became increasingly sedentary and established themselves in the basin of the Grand Canal.

Predators are often another organism's prey, and likewise prey are often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey themselves. And although we humans know little about how plants defend themselves from pests, it makes sense that they would, as they may have evolved the ability to provide their ecosystem with the resources needed to support the defense measures of their cells.

The blue jay-insect-plant relationship begins with the insects that prey upon blue jays, in the form of ants that eat green-stunted insects, specifically aphids. Aphids live on the underside of aphid-carrying leaves. When these leaves are touched with water, these aphids burst and release spores into the water. This spreads the infection from plant to plant, infecting all of them.

The term "house music" is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse listened to house music and dance beats from 1978 to 1979, and continued playing them long after the club had closed down. In the Chicago Tribune, a reporter wrote on September 8, 1978: "The music which filled most of the music-room for at least the last hour of the Warehouse dance party had a different and more unusual name: house music..." The reporter found a number of house DJs while working there, most notably DJ John Berardi, and even included his photograph in a caption: "The most recognizable man at the party is John Berardi the DJ, an electronic-music pioneer who spent much of his life mixing Chicago house... As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. This revival was facilitated by the political unification of its component territories in the West and the East, the Christianization of most of the Eastern Roman Empire and the establishment of the Byzantine emperors. The Byzantine Empire enjoyed peace and prosperity until its collapse in the late 5th century and its revival for the first time in nearly four centuries. Its recovery from centuries of neglect and turmoil owed much to the Byzantine Empire's ability to integrate its various fragments by using its central governance to ensure the internal stability of its disparate regions.

Background

The Eastern Roman Empire began after the Roman conquest of Parthia in the late 3rd century BCE and its decline in the 4th century, which followed the rise and fall of the Roman Republic. It reached its greatest power in the century after the Roman emperor Hadrian (117–35 CE). The empire was divided

Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials. Although the Islamic religious calendar and Islamic tradition had long established a fixed calendar which only measured 365 days, the Muslim caliphs adopted a different lunar calendar which measured 366 days with 29 days of 30-degree daylight.

The Islamic lunar calendar had been adopted by the first Umayyad caliph Abū ‘Ubayd ibn Khaldun and confirmed by Caliph Umar ibn al-Khattab, the first Islamic caliph. After Abū‘l-Qasim’s death in 651 ce, the Umayyad caliphate moved into Baghdad and used the Muslim Arab caliphal calendar. By August 1805, Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike out from his French territories and invade Egypt. Even if the British did not have ships large enough to mount serious operations in the Red Sea, the French navy could not be idle and could provide a serious fleet to blockade British Mediterranean ports. Even if the British could seize the straits of Suez and the Red Sea, the French could seize the oil fields and vital trade routes leading to India, thus completely destroying British power in the Mediterranean. To make his plan even more aggressive, Napoleon made an assault on the southern coast of Britain, in order to sever Anglo-French commerce in the Indian Ocean.

As soon as he learned that Britain was ready to declare war, Napoleon quickly realized that he could not invade Egypt with a weak army. French and Anglo-French reinforcements, along with the naval blockade of the British Isles, could not help.

The independence of the Thirteen Colonies in North America in 1783 after the American War of Independence caused Britain to lose some of its oldest and most valuable assets. One of these was the Hudson Bay Company, which had been founded in 1770 as a company based in Quebec with the intent of exploiting gold and fur trading routes between the Arctic and the Great Lakes region. With the passage of the Stamp Act and the Post Office Act in 1765 which imposed a tax on British shipping in order to support the war effort, the Hudson Bay Company's ships were confiscated outright. The company's trading operations were crippled and it was forced to dissolve. But the Company managed to find a way to avoid extinction, and in the 18th century they managed to buy back the crown lands in the Hudson Bay and Mackenzie districts. On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for the creation of two separate countries that were later to become Israel and most of the surrounding area, and the establishment of a Palestinian State in the West Bank, East Jerusalem, the Gaza Strip, the Golan Heights (the future of Syria’s Golan Heights), and a portion of Lebanon. Following the plan’s adoption, negotiations with the Arab League began a few months later. Negotiations between the Arab and British Mandate governments began in March 1948.

In March, the Arab League requested that the partition plan be implemented immediately. The request was immediately endorsed by the League as a condition for continued British support of the plan; the Arab states made the same demand on 20 December, when they accepted Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion’s withdrawal from a meeting of the League. In some regions, such as the Aragonese and the Balearic Islands, there is a thriving English speaking culture. It is estimated that more than 80% of Catalans consider themselves to be bilingual and many of them have English as a second language. The English language is more widespread in the province of Valencia and it occupies an important position in public education.

Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a revolution which has already begun, seems to anticipate some dire consequences." But Burke did not want England to become embroiled in a revolutionary war with France, and the French Revolution had, in effect, put an end to that threat. Therefore, in his second letter to the French ambassador on 15 August, Burke declared the French Revolution an act of usurpation: "It cannot be too often repeated that our conduct towards the [French] government has been dictated by a spirit of justice and moderation; that we have never attacked or threatened them, and our conduct has been dictated by the best sentiments of friendship and good-will."

Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. In the spring of 1800, Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy, aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when the French army entered the war. The Austrian and Austrian-Hungarian governments feared disaster—and, by the standards of the time, had cause to worry after several earlier defeats on Italian soil—but with the French occupying Italy's southern frontier, Austria's forces were thrown into a defensive posture. By June, however, the Austrian army had been driven back to Milan, and by the spring of 1805, Napoleon had assembled an invasion army of 90,000 men. His entry into the campaign turned into a long campaign of attrition.

The Russian army (with the exception of the cavalry) had never fought a total war in the manner of Napoleon's Grande Armée, and indeed the only time the Russians had fought a defensive operation was in the Napoleonic Wars. After this initial wave of writing, prose and poetry became more and more accessible to the lay person. The rise of the vernacular book marked the rise of literacy in the West. The "crown of literature" was no longer the privilege of literary elite, such as the poets of Petrarch, Petrarch's friend Geoffrey Chaucer and his son, poet, poet laureate, and political thinker, Geoffrey Chaucer's friend and fellow parliamentarian, John Harington, or the medieval scholar Edward Hall. In an age of literacy, it had become socially acceptable for people to be educated at the same time that they were being educated to understand life, nature and the workings of the world. Some street trams (streetcars) used conduit third-rail current collection. The third rail was below street level. Once the conductor had taken the current from the tram, the current (called "third-rail" in Britain and "power for the conductors" in America) was delivered to the vehicle at each track location. The third rail and the third rail-power were in a fixed position on the right side of the cars. See also Figure 6-31.

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and survival but also for maintenance and function. Among microorganisms, energy can also be provided in one-of-a-kind manner. Energy is the main determinant of growth and metabolic rates (metabolism) of living systems and is therefore usually conserved in biology. It represents the major challenge to identify universal traits or characteristics that are shared among a myriad (or several) diverse organisms. The aim of this challenge is to explore universal metabolic traits through the use of metabolic models, which describe the energy metabolism of a cell at any given moment in time. The challenge also uses this unique opportunity to establish the concept of energy efficiency by comparing metabolism of different organisms that vary in size and energy requirements under otherwise identical conditions. This comparison will reveal the best set of traits or characteristics that may underlie the differences in energy metabolism among organisms. Metabolic energy

The authors' first point is a timely reminder that communication studies has never been, historically, a unified discipline.

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid are all widely regarded to be his masterpiece, and were for long considered his major poems: they contain perhaps more literary significance than any other surviving Latin text. They make up perhaps the best known literary work in Latin. These poems, it will be recalled, were probably the first works to be written down in Latin: Virgil wrote and recited the Aeneid himself, and his epic probably took up more than half of his lifetime of writing activity. The other poems, in other words, almost certainly owe something to Virgil. NASA's proposed shuttle was the successor to Project Mercury that would send America to the moon, along with a crew. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the island is covered in basaltic andesite and andesite, with lava fields in the north and west). The main terrain feature is the massive, rugged granite ranges of the eastern cape and the central plateau. The climate along this coastline is hot and sunny, with an average temperature of 27° C (81° F). It has a dry winter rainy season and an average temperature of 23° C (73° F). There are no tropical elements to speak of in the air or on land. The main landfalls are the Cap de la Hague and the Cap de la Breccia. The climate is very similar to the island of Ascension, thus it is sometimes called Ascension West. Average temperatures along the coast are between 20° C (68° F) in the winter to 27° C (81° F) in the summer

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between him and the Roman Church. In this he failed, and the papal bull of the interdict was ignored until 1188. The interdict left Innocent in peace but deeply scarred as a loyal subject of Rome for the rest of his life. The most obvious result of the interdict was the widespread use of the papal bull as the instrument of policy within the territories of the empire. Canadian football originated in Britain in the 18th century and spread to North America around 1817, where it was first played in the United States. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: The Alps (in the south and east) are formed of the western part of southern Switzerland; the Jura Mountains (in the north and centre) consist of several parallel mountain chains running north-south (Jura and Appenzell); and the Engadine (on the north-eastern plains) is a large, largely mountainous plateau.

Switzerland is an independent republic of about 82 million people. It is highly diverse internally, with people from over 140 nationalities. Swiss identity was born during the Great War, which was fought between Switzerland and Germany following the First World War. The German population was expelled and Switzerland itself formed as a result of Switzerland-German treaties. Switzerland has continued to be a sovereign state of the Federal Union since Switzerland and Germany were re-unified in 1990.

As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that all education was waqf was particularly pronounced. In the early Islamic age, it was held by rulers, scholars, and even learned individuals, that it was not a duty to acquire any property in order to teach something of benefit to others. The madrasa and the knowledge gained in it were considered merely a gift to the community and the recipients were free to use it or sell it. The madrasa, however, was a place of study which, in the view of its founder, the Prophet Muhammad, was an essential means of the improvement of society; for it was there that Muhammad was able to correct error and prevent moral corruption. Such views were strongly endorsed by many jurists of the early Islamic age. Moreover, they tended to pervade Islamic scholarship as a whole as Muhammad grew older and as he began to travel and to communicate
